_prev_prog_3.Description:
Olefins 3

process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.
Polyvinyl Chloride process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.
Utilities 3 process utilizes same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to the process.
Ethylene Glycol process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.
Vinyl Chloride Monomer process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.
High Density Polyethylene process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.
Linear Low Density Polyethylene process utilizes the same Prevention Program specified in the Olefins 1 prevention program description.  Dates have been added specific to this process.

Olefins 1 - This program decription is typical for all processes.



Formosa Plastics Industrial Park, located on F-M 1593 in Point Comfort, Texas, is operated by Formosa Plastics Corporation, Texas (FPC-TX). FPC-TX is a vertically integrated organization. It consists of 19 "covered process" operations. The facility is located in the city of Point Comfort, Calhoun County, Texas. The facility currently employs approximately full time 2350 employees in addition 500 contractors.



The Risk Management Plan (RMP) was prepared by the Corporate Process Safety Management Coordinator. Each operating unit has appointed one individual as the person responsible for implementation of the RMP in that Unit. The Environmental, Health and Safety Department, through the Emergency Response Coordinator, oversees, provides guidance, and audits the RMP activities of the operating units.



Compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119: On May 26, 1992, OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule went into effect. FPC-TX is covered under this rule. The PSM rule consists of fourteen (14) elements. The facility has developed and implemented the fourteen elements of this rule.



Even though the facility is large the entire site utilizes the same Prevention program throughout the site.  The Olefins unit will be used as a representative unit and the prevention programs of that unit will be reflective of the entire site.    The hazards associated with the chemicals used in the process, requires the unit to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management rule (29 CFR 1910.119), N-FPA 58 (Storage and handling of liquefied petroleum gases), Spill Prevention Control & Countermeasure program, and other applicable Resource Conservation & Recovery Act rules (RCRA). The equipment installed in the unit was designed based on either ASTM, ANSI, or ASME standards. Before starting the unit, a process hazard analysis (PHA) as required by OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 was completed. The methodologies used were Hazard and Operability methods. Since the last PHA study, additional mitigation systems have been installed.



During the study, the PSM Team evaluated major hazards like: toxic gas release; fire; explosion; runaway reaction; polymerization, over-pressurization and overfilling tanks, reactors, etc; contamination of the chemical; corrosion of pipes; equipment failure; loss of cooling, heating, electricity and instrument air; and natural disasters like floods and hurricanes.



Based on the hazards, the Team insured that there were adequate process controls like: vents; relief valves and rupture disks to insure that holding vessels do not fail in case of overfilling or over-pressurization; check valves to insure that the chemicals do not flow back into equipment containing incompatible materials; flares in case of a gas release; manual/ automatic shutoffs and excess flow device to prevent unwanted discharges; alarms and procedures for the operator to take action in case of a process upset; interlocks to insure that the system shuts down in case of an emergency; emergency power supply for equipment to keep functioning until the system can been shut down during utility failure; quench system to cool down heat generating reactions; purge system to ensure that a gas release does not cause an explosion and process area detectors to warn the unit in advance of-the impending danger of a gas release.



In case there was an incident, the Team also evaluated the mitigation systems like: sprinkler, foam and water deluge systems to either dilute or keep below the explosion point of a gas release; dikes to ensure that the release does not spread and contaminate the surrounding ground; and neutralization system to ensure that the released chemical becomes non-hazardous to the environment.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Formosa Plastics Industrial Park, located on F-M 1593 in Point Comfort, Texas, is operated by Formosa Plastics Corporation, Texas (FPC-TX). FPC-TX is a vertically integrated organization. It consists of 19 "covered process" operations, and four support organizations. The facility is located in the city of Point Comfort, Calhoun County, Texas. The facility currently employs approximately 2350 employees.



The "Covered Processes" are:

Olefins 1

Olefins 2

Olefins 3

Polypropylene 1

Polypropylene 2

High Density Polyethylene 1

High Density Polyethylene 2

High Density Polyethylene 3

Linear Low Density Polyethylene

Low Density Polyethylene

Polyvinyl Chloride

Vinyl Chloride Monomer

Ethylene Glycol

Inland Traffic

Specialty PVC

Utilities

Inventory Control

Chlor-Alkali



The Risk Management Plan (RMP) was prepared by the Corporate Process Safety Management Specialist. Each operating unit has appointed one individual as the person responsible for implementation of the RMP in that Unit. The Environmental, Health and Safety, and the Process Safety Management Departments, through the Emergency Response Coordinator, oversee, provide guidance, and audit the RMP activities of the operating units.



Compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119: On May 26, 1992, OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule went into effect. FPC-TX is covered under this rule. The PSM rule consists of fourteen (14) elements. The facility has developed and implemented the fourteen elements of this rule.



COVERED PROCESS - BRIEF DESCRIPTION



Olefins 1 & 2



Combined, Olefins 1 and Olefins 2 have twenty-three pyrolysis furnaces used to crack a range of feedstock consisting of C5 cut, propane (3), natural gas liquids (NGL) (2), naphtha (4), and an ethane/propane mixture (1). The resulting products are hydrogen, methane, ethylene (7), propylene (8), a mixed C4 product (9), pyrolysis gasoline (10), and pyrolysis fuel oil (11). The furnaces are fired with fuel gas (5).  The mater

ials listed as flammable mixtures contain 1, 3 butadiene, 2-butene-trans, 3-methyl-1-butene, butane, vinyl acetylene, isopentane, and pentane.The Frac II unit in Olefins 2 is a fractionator unit that takes a Y grade feed via pipeline and C4 Plus stream from the existing NGL fractionator (FHC-1) and separates the feed through distillation. The two feeds are separated into Ethane, Propane and N-Butane Plus to be used as feed stock for the Olefins units and an IsoButane Product and C6 Plus Product that are sent to storage for export. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower. 



Olefins 3



Olefins 3 has fourteen pyrolysis furnaces used to crack an ethane feed. The resulting products are hydrogen, methane, ethylene, propylene, a mixed C4 product, pyrolysis gasoline, and pyrolysis fuel oil. The furnaces are fired with fuel gas. The materials listed as flammable mixtures contain 1,3-butadiene, butenes,butanes, isoprene, pentane, pentene, and propane. Isobutane is used in a heat exchange process to heat ethylene and ethane feeds for use. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower. A 29% ammonia solution is fed to SCR units on the furnace and boiler stacks to control NOx.

 



Polypropylene 1



The Polypropylene I Unit utilizes BASF gas-phase reactor technology to produce polypropylene resin using propylene supplied from the Olefins Plant. Each production line has an independent Polymerization Area, Extrusion Area and Silo Area. Common to all production lines are the Raw Material Tank Farm, Purification Area, and Catalyst Preparation Area.



All raw materials, propylene, hydrogen, nitrogen, ethylene, propylene oxide, and hexane are purified in molecular sieve columns to remove carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and moisture. Pellets from the drier are sent to the Pellet Blending Silos for mixing to develop a homogeneous product. From the blending silos, the pellets are sent to the Pellet Product Silos for temporary storage. The PP pellets (L)

are then loaded into railcars and sent to customers. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant and chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Polypropylene 2



The Polypropylene II Unit utilizes Chisso/Amoco technology to produce polypropylene resin using propylene supplied from the Olefins Plant. The Polypropylene II Unit has two independent production lines, Train No. 1 and Train No. 2. Each production line has an independent Polymerization Area, Extrusion Area and Silo Area. Common to both production lines are the Raw Material Tank Farm, Purification Area, and Catalyst Preparation Area.



All raw materials, hydrogen, nitrogen, ethylene, and hexane are purified in molecular sieve columns to remove carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and moisture. Pellets from the drier are sent to the Pellet Blending Silos for mixing to develop a homogeneous product. From the blending silos, the pellets are sent to the Pellet Product Silos for temporary storage. The PP pellets (L) are then loaded into railcars and sent to customers.  Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



High Density Polyethylene 1



The HDPE I plant is composed of the following sections: Catalyst Preparation, Ethylene Purification, Polymerization, Hexane Removal and Powder Drying, Extrusion, and Hexane Recovery and Refining. Ethylene, hydrogen, 1-butene, and hexane are fed into the reactor along with the catalyst and co-catalyst (titanium tetrachloride).



The polymerization process is a slurry process with hexane as the carrier solvent. After the polymerization step, the polyethylene slurry is sent first to the stripping section to recover hexane and then to the drying section. The dry polyethylene powder is transferred to the pelletizing section. The powder, mixed with additives and stabilizers, is then injected into the extruder. The resulting stabilized polyethylene melt is then is pelletized. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



High Density Polyeth

ylene 2



In the HDPE II Plant, polymerization occurs in iso-butane slurry using high activity proprietary catalyst in a loop reactor. The HDPE II Plant has the capability of producing different grades of products for various applications by customers. The HDPE II Plant is broken down into the following sections: Catalyst Preparation and Activation, Feed Preparation, Polymerization, Gas Recovery, Extrusion / Blending & Storage / Rail Car Loading.



The polymerization process reaction is continuous and occurs in a slurry phase with iso-butane as the carrier solvent. The slurry is directed to the High Pressure Flash Chamber where gases and light hydrocarbons are volatilized and exit through the top of the chamber. Ultimately the polymer is pelletized and then transferred to blending silos before being loaded for product shipping. 



High Density Polyethylene 3



HDPE3 is a Univation Technology process that consist of seven areas that produce either High Density Polyethylene or Low Linear Polyethylene.  Area 1 includes Raw materials include Comonomer(C4/C6) nitrogen, hydrogen, ICA(Isopentane) and T2(triethylealuminum). In area 1 are comonomer purification and nitrogen purification. Area 2 of the Univation system are Ethylene purification and Nitrogen regeneration system. Area 4 is our reaction system that can produce 3 grades of polyethylene, UcatJ, BMC, and Acclaim. This area also includes cycle gas compressor and a closed loop reactor that discharges powder through the product discharge system. Area 5A is resin degassing. This area includes our product purge bin and rotary feeder that crushes chunks of poly before going to extrusion. Area 5B is Vent Recovery that recovers ethylene and nitrogen. Area 5E is our seed bed system which allows for quick grade changes and intermediate resin storage. Area 6 is resin additive handling to prep the poly before going into the extruder. Are 7 is pelleting before rail car loading. 



Linear Low Density Polyethylene



The LLD

PE Plant is designed to produce Linear Low Density Polyethylene using two parallel reactor lines. The process employs a gas phase fluidized bed reactor in which ethylene and co-monomers are polymerized using a proprietary catalyst. Ethylene, hydrogen, and a co-monomer are reacted with injected pre-polymer powder in a fluidized bed reactor to produce LLDPE. This product is continuously withdrawn via a lateral withdrawal system for degassing and downstream process. The virgin powder is received and blended with additives for extrusion and pelletization. The product pellets are then pneumatically transferred to the product storage area.  1-Butene and 1-hexene are used as co-monomers and Tri-N-Octyl Aluminum is a co-catalyst for reaction.  Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.



Low Density Poylethylene



LDPE makes Low-Density-Polyethylene (LDPE). Our main feedstock is ethylene which is compressed a number of times up to 3000bar. Inside of our reactor we use organic peroxides to initiate the polymerization reaction that converts ethylene into polyethylene. Once made, the LDPE melt is extruded and sent to railcars to ship to our customer. Other than ethylene, we use a small amount of propylene to modify the LDPE to be within product specifications. 



Poly Vinyl Chloride



The PVC process is suspension polymerization. The general overall process involves the suspension of liquid vinyl chloride monomer in a continuous water phase. The sole function of the water diluent is to facilitate heat removal from the polymerization reaction. The reaction is initiated most commonly with organic peroxide soluble in the monomer phase. PVC slurry is centrifuged and then dried. The clean dry PVC is stored in silos, prior to being sold by railcar, tank truck, one ton bags, and 25 kg bags.



Vinyl Chloride Monomer



EDC is formed by oxychlorination of ethylene. Four oxychlorination trains are used to combine ethylene, hydrogen chloride, and oxygen to form ethylen

e dichloride. Purified EDC (10) is thermally cracked into VCM and HCl in the EDC Crackers. The VCM produced in the furnaces is purified, washed, dried, and sent to the Polyvinyl Chloride department for conversion to PVC. HCl (6) is also purified to meet the quality required as the raw material for the oxychlorination section. EDC is recycled back to the process. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Ethylene Glycol



The Ethylene Glycol plant produces monoethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and triethylene glycol. The glycols are produced in two major steps. Oxygen from the Air Separation Plant (ASP) is reacted with ethylene from the Olefins Plant to form ethylene oxide (EO). EO is produced in the Scientific Design licensed glycol reaction and scrubbing section utilizing Mitsubishi reactors. This safe process begins with only 10 percent EO in a hydrolysis process to produce EG. There is no storage of EO on the site. If the EG unit is not running, the EO unit is shut down. The glycol is distilled into MEG, DEG, and TEG products. All process vents, except for the carbon dioxide regeneration vent, are directed to an incinerator. Flammable mixture of ethylene and ethane is used in the process. Methane is used as a carrier during reaction. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Specialty PVC



Specialty Poly-Vinyl Chloride or SPVC involves the co-polymerization of VCM (Vinyl Chloride Monomer) and VAM (Vinyl Acetate Monomer). The process produces a fine, white powder that has many end product applications including: flooring, carpet backing, automobile underbody coatings, anti-fog applications, medical gloves, furniture, road cones, and many more. The production of SPVC involves three separate processes: (1) Emulsion Process; (2) Suspension-blending resin process and (3) Suspension-copolymer process. Chlorine is utilized for biocide in cooling water tower.  



Inland Traffic



Inland Traffic receives various liquid produc

ts from the Chlor-Alkali, EG, and Frac 2 Departments.  The department then loads them into trucks and railcars.  Caustic is stored in tanks prior to loading or transfer to the Marine Traffic Department.  Ethylene Dichloride (EDC) is stored in tanks prior to transfer to the VCM, Marine Traffic, or EG Departments.  Ethylene Glycol, mono ethylene glycol, diethylene glycol, and tri ethylene glycol, is stored in tanks prior to loading or transfer to marine traffic.  Isobutane is received from the Frac 2 department and loaded directly into railcars.  Inland Traffic receives propylene feedstock via railcars for the Olefins 1 unit.  Propylene is off loaded and transferred to Olefins 1.



Utilities



The Utilities process provides utilities-water, electricity, steam and wastewater treatment for the entire FPC-TX site. For a defined RMP process - Utilities uses chlorine for water treatment.



Inventory Control 



Inventory Control serves as a central issuing and receiving entity for the entire FPC-TX site. For a defined

RMP process - Inventory Control serves as a central location for on-site delivery of full 1 Ton Chlorine cylinders and pick-up for empty 1 Ton Chlorine cylinders. Full chlorine cylinders are stored and issued to each process on an as need basis.





Utilities 3



The Utilities 3 plant provides electricity, steam, instrument air for the entire FPC-TX site, as well as process waste and cooling tower blowdown to the Combined Waste Treatment Plant. For a defined RMP process - Utilities 3 uses chlorine as a biocide in the cooling tower.





Chlor-Alkali



The Chlor-Alkali process receives brine that is electrolytically separated into hydrogen, sodium hydroxide and chlorine. The chlorine is washed, dried and compressed. The end product is used in the production of 1, 2-dichloroethane process.`







HAZARDS OF THE PROCESS



The hazards associated with the chemicals used in all the referenced "COVERED PROCESSES" requires the unit to comply with OSHA's Proc

ess Safety Management rule (29 CFR 1910.119), NFPA 58 (Storage- and handling of liquefied petroleum gases), Spill Prevention Control & Countermeasure program, and other applicable Resource Conservation & Recovery Act rule (RCRA). The equipment installed in the units was designed based on either ASTM, ANSI, or ASME standards. Before starting the each unit, a process hazard analysis (PHA) as required by OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 was completed. The methodology used was the Hazards and Operability Study. Since the last PHA study, process parameters have been changed, and additional process controls, process detection systems and mitigation systems have been installed.



During the study, the PHA Team evaluated major hazards like, toxic gas release; fire; explosion; runaway reaction; over pressurization and overfilling tanks, reactors, etc.; equipment failure; and loss of cooling, heating, electricity and instrument air.



Based on the hazards, the Team insured that there were adequate process controls like, vents; relief valves and rupture disks to insure that holding vessels do not fail in case of overfilling or over pressurization; check valves to insure that the chemicals do not flow back into equipment containing incompatible materials; flares in case of gas release; manual/ automatic shutoffs and excess flow device to prevent unwanted discharges; alarms and procedures for the operator to take action in case of a process upset; interlocks to insure that the system shuts down in case of an emergency; emergency air and power supply for equipment to keep functioning until the system can been shut down during utility failure; and process area detectors to warn the unit in advance of the impeding danger of a gas release. In case there was an incident, the Team also evaluated the mitigation systems like sprinkler and water deluge systems to either dilute or keep below the explosion point of a gas release; and dikes to insure that the release does not spread and co

ntaminate the surrounding ground.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



5-year accidental release history: There were 3 release incidents (10-05-16, 7-13-17, 12-22-17) from a covered process involving a regulated substance that met the reporting requirements per the RMP regulation in the past five year



SUPPORT ORGANIZATIONS



Administration Department



Plans, organizes, directs, and controls the activities of the administrative services to carry out the administrative support operations at the company.



Inventory Control: Total commitment to providing service by ensuring that proper material stock levels are maintained, all materials received meet specifications, and right materials of the best quality are delivered at the correct time.



Human Resources: Provides quality service to Operation Units in Human Resource management, i. e., securing consistency in the applications, policy, training, and providing timely answers to employee's questions, complaints, and concerns.



General Affairs: To provide reliable quality service in ground maintenance, office administration, and general affairs services.



Technical Department



Technical Department's responsibility is to provide laboratory-scale analyses and support to Operations for process control, environmental compliance, and product development. The personnel handle small amounts of hazardous gases and liquids in their daily functions.



Environmental Department, Health and Safety Department, Process Safety Management Department



The Environmental, Health and Safety, Process Safety Management Departments perform three major functions:

1) Policy writing

2) Training program development

3) Auditing of facility compliance



The Corporate ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH, & SAFETY POLICY

"The company is committed to the protection of the environment, the safety and health of our employees and the community.



This is accomplished through the use of clear and well documented systems and procedures, proper training

and qualification, high performance expectations, continual improvement in pollution prevention, minimization and recycling, as well as workplace hazard analysis and prevention.



Through the joint efforts of every employee, we maintain full compliance with all applicable environmental and safety laws and regulations, conserve natural resources, reduce wastes and keep our workplace free of health and safety hazards, for ourselves, for the community and for future generations."



Environmental is divided into two sections: Air Management and Water & Waste Management.



The Water and Waste Management Section is responsible to seek continual improvements in pollution prevention, waste minimization and recycling with regard to applicable water and solid hazardous waste laws. Through the development of policies and procedures, training, and auditing, the Water and Waste Management section maintain compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations.



The Air Management Section is responsible for policy development with regards to applicable air laws and regulations. Routine auditing of the facility ensures continued compliance and enhances all employees' environmental awareness. This section is also responsible for the operation of offsite air monitoring systems.



Health is divided into two sections: Industrial Hygiene and Medical.



The Industrial Hygiene Section is responsible for policy development and training in the areas of physical and chemical stressors. The section also audits these programs to maintain compliance with regulations. 



The Medical Section provides a comprehensive physical examination program in accordance with OSHA standards. The staff utilizes the latest in medical equipment and technology to treat medical emergencies for company and contractor employees. This group provides assistance for non-occupational illnesses and injuries, coordinates Worker's Compensation claims, provides immunizations for hepatitis and tetanus vaccine

s and facilitates return to work for occupational and non-occupational cases.



Safety is divided into three sections: Safety, Emergency Response, and Security.



Safety is responsible for policy development as well as Facility auditing to check compliance with both Formosa policy and Federal safety standards.



The Emergency Response section is responsible for management and mitigation of emergencies (Fire, Haz-Mat, Rescue, and Medical) which may occur in the Facility. The Emergency Response section supervises and trains. Operations group personnel assigned to the Plant Emergency Response Team (ERT). 



Security is responsible for policy development and daily oversight of facility physical security and compliance.



Process Safety Management Department is responsible for policy development as well as Facility auditing to check compliance with both Formosa policy and Federal PSM/RMP standards. It is also reponsible for updating and maintaining the RMP submittal.



Maintenance Department



The FPC, Texas Maintenance Department is a multilevel Department established to maintain and increase equipment reliability and efficiency. Following are brief descriptions of the Maintenance Departments and their inter-relationships within this Facility.



Central Maintenance



Central Maintenance includes overall maintenance management and staff, maintenance discipline management, maintenance shop, mechanical integrity, and civil maintenance



Maintenance Management (A. V P)



Responsible for overall Maintenance Department functions. The Maintenance A. V. P. is the primary contact point between Maintenance and Operations Management and the General Manager and Vice President of Operations.

Maintenance Shop & Services

Provides machine shop and services for rotating equipment support, fabrication services, garage, fuel service, hydro blasting, vacuum truck service, valve repairs, welding services, rotating equipment support, fabrication and small project services, garag

e, hydro blasting, vacuum truck service and other maintenance services for both Operations and the other maintenance departments.  









Civil Maintenance



Provides civil maintenance support to all Departments. In addition, they are responsible for railcar and rail repair.



Mechanical Integrity



Provides mechanical integrity support to all departments.  



Maintenance Staff



Maintenance Staff provides maintenance cost, performance and environmental reporting coordination and services for all Maintenance Departments and administrative support for entire Maintenance Department.



High Voltage Power 

Provides the site with assistance for high voltage power in regards to grounding assurance, transformer bushing, overhead protection, replacement of underground cables, cathodic protection wells, as well as other High voltage services to the site.



Maintenance Satellite Shops



The Maintenance Department has an established Satellite Shop at each operating plant. These satellite shops provide Mechanical, Electrical, and Instrument Maintenance Services to the Operating Units. The following descriptions apply to all three Maintenance Disciplines. Interactions with Operating Units are through established Equipment Route Checks, scheduled preventative maintenance, and analysis of abnormal equipment conditions. In addition to regularly scheduled maintenance activities, the Satellite shops meet weekly with Operations to discuss concerns, schedules, and abnormal analysis results. Various Maintenance services are also performed upon request from Operations through the work order system. This system allows requested work to be managed and completed in a timely manner.



The Maintenance Organization as a whole exists to support Operations and provide equipment reliability, efficiency, and therefore equipment safety.
